history.content: I thought CS 70 was listed as an official prereq of 189. Regardless, if (allegedly) you have already studied probability yourself I guess you will be fine. EE127 will help a lot.

children.subject:
(OP)
Hi Garrett - thank you for taking the time to answer my question!  (And also many thanks for creating the guide PDF)


I had taken note of your disclaimer on Page 1, which is why I am hoping to learn from the EE/CS community what they feel are useful concepts to study that may not be mentioned in the guide.  I also recognize the guide serves only as a introduction to some prerequisite topics; hence, I appreciate any tips on resources I can use to delve further into the listed material (I'll be sure to check out the Stanford links Prof Shewchuk posted on his site).

I will look into the topics mentioned in your reply above.  Actually feeling slightly relieved, because CE 93 did teach the all topics you mentioned.  However it was a very straight-forward class and I've heard CS70 has a reputation to be difficult/rigorous, which is what worried me about my preparation.  I'll make sure to have Gaussian distributions, continuous probability, density functions, and basic stat concepts properly reviewed and under my belt by end of summer.

Thanks again!
(And sorry for misspelling your name in my first post!)

Hi Garrett,

As someone who is in 70 and will likely be taking 189 before taking 126 or another rigorous probability course, I'm wondering if you have any resources that you can recommend that are helpful for practicing continuous probability, sampling, estimation, and the other topics you mentioned. Would the material for this be found in, say, the books used for Stat 134/135? Thanks!

The guide states very clearly that it is not intended as a replacement for the prerequisite classes.  That said, if you're going to be self-studying, it would be good to spend plenty of time on normal (Gaussian) distributions.  Even many students who have taken CS 70 seem inadequately familiar with continuous probability, density functions, etc.  It also would be good to study basic statistics: sampling, estimation (esp. maximum likelihood estimation), and Bayes theorem.

(OP)
@ 1st Anon student, thanks for your reply!  Yes, I'm aware it is an official prereq - I'm hoping to get a sense from people who have taken CS189 on whether self-studying any prerequisite probability concepts is realistic/sufficient as preparation.  I won't have time to take CS70 in my schedule (next year is my senior year).  Glad to hear 127 will be helpful and self-studying is acceptable in your view.

history.content: You need to learn probability well and be comfortable with proofs, etc. at the level of 70 --- that is, with twists. The polynomials material in 70 is also very relevant. Having 16B and 127 will be good for you, but you might have to fill in gaps for 70 material. Probability is notoriously hard to self-study. There is a way of thinking and reasoning that you need to internalize.

children.subject:
(OP)
Thanks Professor Sahai!  I'll add CS70's polynomials material to my study list.  It sounds like past CS70 material (past exams, homeworks, worksheets, webcasts) can be a valuable resource in helping fill any gaps.  I appreciate your warning about the difficulty of self-studying probability and truly internalizing the way of thinking.  I'll try my best this summer.  Looking forward to taking CS189 with you in the Fall!
How hard would 189 be without having taken Math 53?

history.content:
Dear Fellow Students (and Professor Sahai),

I have taken the prerequisites Math 53 and Math 54, but not CS70.  I have taken CE 93 ("Data Analysis for Engineers"), which has some probability, but I felt it was rather light.
1) Granted I self-study probability topics over the summer (~6 hrs a week, 12 weeks), would you recommend I take CS189 in the Fall with Prof Bartlett and Prof Sahai?

My plan was to go through the probability topics listed here (CS 189 TA Garett Thomas' guide) and whatever past CS70 probability material I can access online.  2) What are key probability topics you would recommend knowing going into CS189?

[I'm also making an assumption the discrete math component of CS70 isn't a prerequisite for CS189...]

Other info:  I'm an Energy Engineer completing a minors in EECS/ME.  I have taken EE16A; currently taking EE127, EE16B.  I will take three other techs next semester.

Thank you all in advance for insight and tips!  I really appreciate it :)
history.subject: CS189 without CS70?
